profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Shaftsbury, Bennington County, Vt., September 21, 1808; attended the common schools, and was graduated from Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., in 1835; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1838 and commenced practice in Troy, N.Y.; recorder of the city of Troy 1844-1852; elected as a Republican to the Thirty-fifth, Thirty-sixth, and Thirty-seventh Congresses (March 4, 1857-March 3, 1863); appointed by President Lincoln an associate justice of the supreme court of the District of Columbia and served from March 11, 1863, until he voluntarily retired January 13, 1879; died near Sligo, Montgomery County, Md., July 7, 1879; interment in the Danforth family lot adjacent to West Lawn Cemetery, Williamstown, Berkshire County, Mass.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Barnard, Job. Early days of the Supreme court of the District of Columbia. Washington: N.p., 1919.
Olin, Abram B. Admission of Kansas. [Washington, D.C.: Buell & Blanchard, printers 1858].

researchRecord.name: ca. 186?, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Abram Baldwin Olin to O. H. Browning, written in 186?. The letter was also signed by D. W. C. Clarke. Abram Olin writes regarding supporting H. Z. Haynes (?) for the office of Commissioner of Patents. Other authors: Browning, Orville Hickman, 1806-1881, recipient.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1865, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from David K. Cartter to President Johnson written on June 15, 1865. David K. Cartter writes to recommend a candidate for the post of Register of Deeds. The letter is also signed also by George P. Fisher, Andrew Wylie and A.B. Olin, fellow judges of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts
